Elkridge Home Maker, Smokey Lake

What did early Canadian pioneer eat? Dec. 2nd - 1957

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name (Mrs.) A.G. Pagan
Address ...Lloydminster...
Birthplace ...England...

1. INTERDIETARY HABITS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ...1901...
Where did you set up housekeeping? ...Endeavour, Manitoba...
Where had you been living before that? ...Endeavour, 10 miles North of Russell...
For how many people did you prepare meals? ...my husband, I...
How far was it to your nearest store? ...10 miles...
How often could a visit be made to the store? ...once in two weeks...
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ...sugar, tea, rice, pumpkin seeds, baking powder, dried apricots, dried apples, dried prunes, raisins, currants, salt, baking soda...

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...Mack...
In what quantities did you buy it? ...ten pounds...
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ...$1.25...
How much did you use graham flour? ...half a pound, small quantity...
Whole wheat flour? ...small quantity...
Was flour milled locally? ...yes... How far away? ...100 miles... What year? ...1901...
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...not sure...
What other grain products did you use? ...cornmeal, hominy, buckwheat, barley...
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...no...
How did you grind it? ...not sure...
